bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: IN THE SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITES STATES.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DENTENTION OF SEVENTY-THREE HINDOO ALIENS.
No. 2532 ASSIGNMENT OF ERROR

Come now the petitioning aliens and file the following assignment of errors on which they will rely in the prosecution of their appeal in the above entitled cause to the Supreme Court of the United States from the District Court of the Western Dis- trict of Washington.
I.
The court erred in refusing to grant the writ of habeas corpus.
II.

The court erred in holding the decision of the immigration department final, and that the court would not inter- fere to see justice done where injustice was alleged, as the allegation was made that there was no evidence and that the con- struction of a statute was involved and a legal matter was at issue as to the construction of Section 20, and in holding the immigration decision final and in refusing to examine the evi- dence for the purpose of testing the correctness of petitioners'
allegations
III.
The court erred in refusing to find that the petitioners had been deprived of their constitutional rights under Articles 5, 6, 8, and 14 of the amendments of the Constitution of the United States.
IV.

The court erred in not holding that the examination at Seattle, Washington, after a due and proper exami- nation by the immigration authorities at Manila, after resi- dence in the Philippine Islands for several years, was not an improper examination and an abuse of authority and discre- tion.
V.
The court erred in refusing to hold that the exami- nation and admission at Manila, a regular port of entry, was not final and sufficient.
VI.

The court erred in refusing to find that the warrant of arrest on authority of which the aliens were threatened with deportation, was not faulty and contrary to law and not a sufficient warrant on which to deport the aliens under author- ity of the Act of February 20, 1907, and Section 20 thereof.
VII.

The court erred in refusing to find that the examination was not fair and impartial and in refusing and failing to find that the immigration authorities went outside of the law and acted contrary to law in issuing the warrant and in threatening to deport.
VIII.

That the court erred in refusing to find and failing to find that the immigration department violated the Act of February 20, 1907, and particularly Section 20 thereof, in that no evidence was ever produced show- ing that the aliens came within the confines or within the provisions of said law.
IX.

The court erred in refusing to find that the aliens had never violated any of the provisions of the said Act of February, 20, 1907, and refusing to fina that the immigration department officials transcended the bound of their authority in holding that the aliens had violated the provisions of the Act and came within the provisions thereof.
X.
The court erred in failing to find that the de- cision of the immigration department and the issuing of the warrants was all contrary to law and in direct violation of the Act of February 20, 1907.
XI
The court erred in failing to find that the
